abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey a satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Project results largely
            confirm that the establishment of a flexible mechanism for
            financing demand-driven training activities to strengthen
            labor force qualification, is a viable and interesting
            response to the skills development needs of various economic
            actors, especially in the informal sector. However, project
            implementation underscored that success and sustainability
            hinge on some key elements. Lessons are highlighted as
            follows. The effectiveness and sustainability of mechanisms
            depend heavily on the autonomy granted to the fund, and on
            the extent of private sector "ownership." And, the
            credibility of the mechanism calls for the establishment of
            an adequate-and predictable-system of funding. The
            demand-driven approach, and the organization of fair
            competition among training providers underline the need to
            be able to manage activities smoothly within a predictable
            short- and medium-term framework to sustain training demand,
            and to expedite timely responses to the needs identified.
            Ensuring availability of other inputs such as micro-finance
            and market accessibility is essential to improve the impact
            of training on beneficiaries, especially in the informal
            sector. But, financing a demand-driven training program,
            together with the required beneficiary contribution should
            be accompanied by adequate evaluation work, and suitable
            communication strategies to ensure equitable distribution of grants.

5084872.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Labor Force Development Project in
            Benin, will assist in the start up, and pilot testing of a
            new government program that aims at: increasing the
            availability, quality, and cost effectiveness of labor force
            training; and, at strengthening the public sector capacity
            to monitor, and evaluate labor force training needs, and, at
            improving the private sector training capacity. The
            components will: 1) provide training grants to workers in
            the informal, and modern sectors, and to selected, new labor
            force participants. Priority training programs will be
            identified, and subsequently, contract the provision of
            training with qualified providers. Training proposals will
            be evaluated on the basis of economic interest, social
            equity, technical feasibility, cost estimates, and financial
            planning; 2) develop a strong monitoring, and evaluation
            system, to generate timely information on the implementation
            of the training program, on the market for training, i.e.,
            beneficiary groups' knowledge, and appreciation of the
            Fund's program, and, on the impact of training.
            Longitudinal studies will measure the economic impact, to
            allow progressive policy adjustments, and rationalized
            financial allocations; and, 3) will strengthen the
            institutional development of the Fonds de Developpement de
            la Formation Professionnelle Continue et de
            l'Apprentissage, and finance overseas study, training,
            and technical assistance.
